full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Mrs. Johnson. How are you feeling today?
Client: I'm... I'm okay, I suppose. A bit nervous about revisiting that day again.
Therapist: That's understandable. Remember, you're safe here.
Client: Thank you. It's just... every time I think about it, my heart starts racing.
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're doing great.
Client: Okay... I'll try. It was a warm afternoon. I was walking home from the grocery store. I remember the weight of the bags in my hands...
Therapist: Good. Stay with that memory.
Client: I saw the police car turn the corner. At first, I didn't think much of it. But then it slowed down near me. I felt... uneasy.
Therapist: You're doing well. Keep going.

Client: The officer got out. He was young, probably in his twenties. He asked what I was doing in the neighborhood. I told him I lived there, but he didn't believe me. He... he started getting aggressive.
Therapist: It's okay to feel emotional. You're safe now.
Client: He grabbed my arm. It hurt. I dropped my groceries. I tried to explain, but he wouldn't listen. He pushed me against the car. I was so scared...
Therapist: You're very brave for sharing this. Continue when you're ready.
Client: I could hear my heart pounding in my ears. He was twisting my arm behind my back. I cried out in pain, but he just told me to shut up. I felt so... helpless.
Therapist: It's natural to feel that way. You're handling this well.
Client: My neighbors... they came out when they heard the commotion. They were shouting at the officer, telling him I lived there. But he ignored them. He was so focused on me, so angry...
Therapist: Stay with it. You're doing great.
Client: He slammed me against the hood of the car. I hit my head. Everything was spinning. I thought... I thought he might kill me right there on the street.
Therapist: You're safe now. Take a moment if you need to.
Client: I... I can't... It's too much...
Therapist: That's okay. You've done incredibly well. Let's take a break.
Client: Thank you... I just... I can still feel his hands on me sometimes. It's like I'm right back there.
Therapist: Your feelings are valid. You're showing immense strength.
Client: It's hard to believe that. I feel so weak when I remember it.
Therapist: Facing these memories takes courage. You're anything but weak.
Client: I suppose... It's just... I've lived in that neighborhood for 40 years. And in a moment, I was made to feel like I didn't belong.
Therapist: That must have been very painful. How are you feeling now?
Client: A bit shaky, but... better than I expected. Talking about it... it helps, even though it's hard.
Therapist: I'm glad it's helping. You're making progress.
Client: Thank you. I... I think I'm ready to continue. After my neighbors intervened, the officer finally let me go. But he didn't apologize. He just got in his car and drove away.
Therapist: You're doing great. Keep going.
Client: I was left there, on the sidewalk, with my groceries scattered everywhere. My neighbors helped me up, got my things. I was trembling so much I could barely stand.
Therapist: It's okay to feel those emotions. You're safe here.
Client: I felt so... humiliated. Violated. Like my dignity had been stripped away in front of everyone. I've never felt so small in my life.
Therapist: You're very brave for sharing this. How do you feel now?
Client: Angry. Sad. But... also a little relieved. Talking about it... it's like letting out a breath I've been holding for a long time.
Therapist: That's a positive step. You should be proud of yourself.
Client: Thank you. I... I think I need a moment. This is a lot to process.
Therapist: Of course. Take all the time you need. You've done excellent work today.
